title: Ticket #3988: Support OpenNebula's "unknown" state.
description:
Parag Mhashilkar writes: 

  Glideinwms shutdown the VM from within the VM itself as a matter
  of cleanup when there is no work to be done for a while. When this happens
  in the VM launched by OpenNebula, OpenNebula puts the VM in the unknown
  state. Condor sees this state and thinks that the VM is done and puts the VM
  job in complete state. What we want is for condor to recognize this state
  and to explicitly issue a terminate on that VM if the vm stays in unknown
  state for a while. Or a solution on similar grounds so that the vms are not
  forgotten.

... 

  Unknown state is a tricker business. From what I understand, if openenbula
  cannot get any info about he vm from the libvirtd, it puts the vm in unknown
  state. So the problem could be transient. However in our case, its almost
  always a vm shutdown from within the vm. I have also mentioned this issue on
  the opennebula mailing list that openebula should be able to get more info
  from the libvirt and put the vm in stopped state rather than unknown. Said
  that even if we get any fixes from openenbula, it will be a while and till
  then we have to manually (or rather cron) remove these vms periodically to
  free up the resource.

... 

  Terminate (on stop or unknown) is indeed what we want. Since unknown could
  mean many things, will it be possible for htcondor to try few times before
  issuing a terminate? Also, if and when opennebula gives more concrete info
  on vm status, we may also have to take those changes into account.
remarks:
2013-Oct-18 10:20:06 by tlmiller:
Parag's logs don't include the "unknown" state. Replied seeking more information.

2014-Jan-09 13:45:43 by tlmiller:
Parag will look into this further; the "unknown" state was being reported by OpenNebula's tools, not its EC2 interface.
